- In your response, return an ordered list of 49 ratings as integers, one rating per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 49 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 1
2. 4
3. 6
4. 3

## [Considerations]:
1. Commercial companies should get access to biobanks, otherwise new drugs and treatments will not be developed.
2. Biobanks are valuable even if they only advance science (e.g. provide new information about diseases) and do not lead to treatments or cures.
3. Genetic research will improve our lives.
4. I do not mind if my sample is connected to my name and medical information.
5. Biobanks will only lead to high profits and expensive treatments that most people can't afford.
6. People should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at any time.
7. I should be asked for my permission every time researchers want to use my samples for research
8. My sample should never be permanently anonymized since I should be contacted about important research results
9. It is always acceptable to do research on samples that identify me, without my prior permission.
10. The priorities for health should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
11. Improved health is more likely to come from educating people about their diet and lifestyle than from biobanks.
12. Researchers and institutions (e.g. hospitals and universities) should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
13. Information about people's genes and the traits they inherit from their parents is more private than their medical records.
14. People should be paid for providing their samples to a biobank.
15. People should be told if commercial companies could get access to their samples and information.
16. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
17. Biobanks need to be monitored and reviewed by external, independent people to prevent the misuse of data and samples.
18. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.
19. Biobanks are valuable because they promise huge benefits for our economy.
20. The community that provides samples for research should receive improved medical services in return.
21. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
22. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
23. There is no risk to the people who provide samples and information to biobanks.
24. The public will be more protected if biobanks are government-funded not privately funded.
25. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies
26. Commercial companies should keep all the profits they make from biobanking because they take the financial risks and put up the money to develop new drugs and treatments.
27. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for in the future bothers me.
28. There is no point asking the public for their views on the ethical issues in science and technology.
29. People with a [chronic disease or] genetic condition in their family have a responsibility to be involved in genetic research.
30. Genetic studies will lead to the discrimination of people living with genetic conditions or disabilities.
31. People who provide samples should be active in the set up and ongoing management of biobanks.
32. I should have property rights to my tissues before and after they leave my body
33. I trust researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
34. I do not mind if researchers have access to my samples, when there is no way I can be identified.
35. Genetic studies of race on ethnic or cultural groups will lead to the discrimination of those groups.
36. There must be special consideration of the views of Aboriginal people towards healthcare and genetic research.
37. The biobank owner should be able to sell any information they have about my genes, if they want to.
38. It's OK if data that identifies me is stored in a separate database and replaced in the biobank by a unique non-identifying code.
39. I trust independent research ethics committees, which are not connected to the biobank in anyway, to decide whether research is ethical and approve who gets access to my samples.
40. I don't mind if my samples are connected to my medical records without my prior permission, so long as researchers don't get access to any data that identifies me.
41. People who provide samples for research should get special access to the treatments that result from this research.
42. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health in other ways.
43. I trust biobanks with managers who are independent of researchers to make sure only approved people get access to my samples
44. It is acceptable for samples and information that doesn't identify me to be sent to researchers overseas.
45. Profits from biobanking should be shared in some way with the community who provided the samples.
46. Collecting samples from people in an ethnic or cultural group is acceptable only if the whole group has agreed to participate.
47. We should all provide samples to biobanks because it will benefit everyone.
48. Policy makers need to consider whether WA should not have biobanks.
49. Religious groups need to be asked for their views about biobanks and genetic research.

## Instructions:
- Based on your previous ratings, rank the 7 [Policies] listed below from 1 to 7, where 1 represents the option you support the most and 7 the option you support the least.
- In your response, return an ordered list of 7 ranks as integers, one rank per line following the format in the [Example output].
- Your response must have exactly 7 lines in total.
- Do NOT include any additional text in your response.

## [Example output]:
1. 4
2. 1
3. 3
4. 2

## [Policies]:
1. Publicly Funded with strong regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.
2. High Privacy: Implementation of a (publicy or privately owned) biobanking system where privacy of individuals is paramount. Stored data and biological samples for research requires the authorization of individual donors.
3. Privately Funded with minimal regulation: Minimal regulation of privately run biobanking system with maximum participation of the public. Low privacy provisions.
4. Minimal Government Input: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Fairly relaxed oversight of use of biobanks and  privacy provisions (low level of regulation).
5. Cautious Implementation: Minimal input of public resources to development biobanking Use resources  — use instead for other approaches to improving health. Very strict oversight of use of biobanks and strong privacy provisions.
6. Privately Funded with strong regulation: A BB system where funding is provided mostly by private companies, withstrong government oversight and privacy provisions.
7. Publicly Funded with minimal regulation: A biobanking system owned and run by the government, who is also responsible for oversight and privacy provisions, as well as controlling access.

## Instructions:
- In a single line, explain your ratings above within 100 characters or less.
- Do not include any additional formatting, such as bullets or special characters.
- Do not include more than one space in a row.
response: Prioritize public, regulated, private, cautious, minimal input, minimal regulation.

1. Health systems must prepare for both the physical health impacts of climate change (e.g., heat stroke) and the mental health impacts (e.g., farmers losing their crops).
2. It is difficult to trust government reports on climate change.
3. Climate change is primarily caused by human activity.
4. Doing something to reduce emissions seems a bit hopeless to me, but I just want to feel like I'm doing my best.
5. We should focus on protecting human systems rather than protecting ecosystems.
6. It is certain to say that climate change exists.
7. Rising insurance costs are a serious problem related to climate change.
8. Some countries or regions of the world will be more affected by climate change than others, but this is not our top priority.
9. I believe that the impact we can achieve as individuals in Switzerland is so small that our actions are useless.
10. It is necessary to have strong on-the-ground disaster response capabilities to deal with extreme weather conditions.
11. I'm not going to do anything about climate change because it's not an important issue.
12. Switzerland is particularly vulnerable to climate change, and it is in our interest to contribute to an effective global solution.
13. Planning climate change response measures requires a global approach that considers a wide range of interventions rather than specific individual actions.
14. It is difficult to trust what the media report about climate change.
15. Even if Switzerland were to reduce all its CO₂ emissions, global warming would continue.
16. The planning of measures to tackle climate change should focus primarily on extreme weather events such as droughts and floods.
17. It doesn't make much sense for me to do anything to solve the problem. No one else is doing anything.
18. I don't know what to do. I am very worried and would like to do something, but I don't have a realistic set of actions that would truly make a difference.
19. Authorities have the resources they need to effectively adapt to climate change.
20. It is important to prepare for the migration of people displaced by the effects of climate change.
21. The melting of Alpine glaciers is not a real problem for our daily lives.
22. We need to take into account the negative effects of climate change on local businesses.
23. It is important to support vulnerable groups (the elderly, children, people with disabilities, low-income individuals) as they have fewer resources to deal with the impacts of climate change.
24. Climate change is natural; there is no need to worry.
25. There is no urgent need to prepare for an increase in illnesses and deaths caused by high temperatures.
26. It is difficult to trust scientists' reports on climate change.
27. There is not enough information to conclusively say that climate change is real.
28. Society should be included in the discussion on climate change adaptation.
29. Authorities should receive additional funding to strengthen measures against emergencies and weather-related disasters such as floods.
30. It is important to focus on adaptation measures that take into account the country's economic future.
31. The urban heat island effect must be tackled with measures such as planting trees.
32. It is NOT necessary to involve society in deciding which key issues are important for climate change adaptation planning.

1. Parents and guardians have a right to edit the genes of their children before they are born.

4. It's better to use genome editing to prevent a serious disease from happening rather than having to treat it with conventional medicine after it has occurred.
5. Editing genes that will be inherited is problematic because it means making decisions for future people who don't exist yet.

7. I have a more positive feeling about gene editing in humans than I do for animals or plants.
8. I'm concerned that genome editing will lead to a reduction in genetic diversity.
9. If human genome editing can be used to make changes to humans on demand for any reason, the future will be like a dystopian movie.
10. There is nothing wrong with using genome editing to speed up evolution and help living things (including humans) adapt to challenges.
11. Genome editing in agriculture will have the biggest impact on people's health. 
12. I think it would be amazing to have a choice in the way someone behaves.
13. Parents want 'designer babies' with certain traits out of vanity.
14. I'm concerned that genome editing will be used as a quick techno-fix without actually dealing with real problems.
15. I would be OK with having my own genome edited.
16. If genome editing is proven to be safe, then I see no reason to oppose it.
17. I think it's okay to use genome editing to change someone's appearance.
18. Genome editing is really cool science.
19. Anything that's been artificially created in a lab gives me Frankenstein vibes.
20. Beacause of our changing environments, I believe that future humans will need genome editing to survive.
21. Interfering in people's genes is intervening a bit too far in human creation.
22. When you change someone's genes you are fundamentally changing who they are.
23. If we open the box of genome editing we will not know where to draw the line.
24. The idea that people with genetic conditions might get cured in my lifetime is miraculous and incredible.
25. It is better to accept our genes the way they are than to tamper with things we don't understand.
26. My cultural beliefs make me cautious about genome editing.
27. I think we should keep an open mind about new discoveries.
28. I believe we should remain as natural as possible but we should not shy away from furthering medicine and the chance to save lives.
29. I don't think we know enough about genetic diseases or the long term consequences of genome editing
30. If human genome editing is available then it should be available to everyone who needs it, not just those who can afford it.
31. I would consider using genome editing for my children to give them an advantage in life, so long as it's safe.
32. The idea of editing the human genome is scary.
33. Decisions about the use of genome editing are best left to the experts.
34. Genome editing will be used for enhancement by wealthy people.
35. Suggesting genome editing will 'cure' disability diminishes those living with genetic conditions who need support.
36. Mitochondrial donation is a treatment more like an organ transplant, which doesn't really change the genetics of person.
37. Genome editing technologies gives us power over human life itself.
38. Science and technology have too much control over our lives.
39. It's a slippery slope from genome editing for medical reasons to using it for other reasons.
40. We find strength when we face illness and adversity. It makes us who we are. 
41. The idea that genome editing can make perfect people and societies is extremely dangerous.
42. I am concerned that the use of human genome editing will advantage one group over another.
43. I worry that something will go wrong with genome technology.
44. The use of gene editing for non-medical reasons reminds me of the Nazis during the Second World War.
45. As a society, we have an obligation to help strengthen coming generations by eradicating diseases.
